hedline.hl1: Trying to Make Package Delivery As Easy as Shopping Online

abstract.p: New company, called zBox, creates system to simplify delivery of packages; photo (M)

block.p: Shopping online is usually the easy part: point, click, credit-card number. It's the arrival of the purchases that can be less than convenient, especially if one doesn't happen to be home when the packages arrive.

To help solve the problem of that last mile (and to save a trip to the post office with a yellow Delivery Attempt note in hand or the irritation of playing tag with the courier service), a company called zBox has created what it calls a ''smart home-delivery appliance.'' It is a small box (about 2 1/2 feet wide by 2 feet tall and 2 feet deep), that sits outside your house and is equipped with a proprietary access system and a keypad. Shoppers can instruct online and catalog merchants to send packages through the zBox service. A package delivered with the aid of the zBox technology will have an unique access code on the shipping label, and the driver just has to punch the package code into the keypad on the zBox to open the device and leave the goods. The access code on the zBox changes with each package, but the zBox owners have their own PIN code so they can collect deliveries easily.

Shoppers can instruct online and catalog merchants to send packages through the zBox service. A package delivered with the aid of the zBox technology will have an unique access code on the shipping label, and the driver just has to punch the package code into the keypad on the zBox to open the device and leave the goods. The access code on the zBox changes with each package, but the zBox owners have their own PIN code so they can collect deliveries easily.

The zBox company recently completed a successful test of the product in the San Francisco Bay Area, with 100 consumers and major courier services, like United Parcel Service and Federal Express, participating. ''We really expect, within two years, to have zBoxes in almost every neighborhood in the U.S.,'' said Tony Paikeday, one of the company's founders. The zBox will be available for purchase from the company's Web site (www.zbox.com). The United States Postal Service has just signed an agreement with zBox to promote postal-carrier training for zBox deliveries and the marketing of the device. Other delivery services are likely to participate.

And there's one other aspect of online shopping that the zBox is prepared for: the return of unwanted purchases. A user will be able to return packages by leaving them in the zBox and clicking a button on the company's Web site to have the packages picked up.
